content:
• Friday, July 7, 2017

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: ADVM +2.0%. FMSA +1.9%. TK +1.5%. USLV +1.4%. BGFV +0.8%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: ZN -6.1%. CBL -2.3%. CAMT -2.0%. EZPW -1.9%. WFT -1.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 7 Comments

  • Weekly ETF Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers: REMX +6.6%. VXX +2.5%. BRF +2.2%. EPI +2.1%. XLF +1.5%.
    • Top losers: GAZ -10.1%. GDXJ -6.3%. SLV -6.2%. SIVR -6.2%. UNG -5.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM | 1 Comment
  • SIMO

    Analyst lowers Silicon Motion price target after revenue report; shares down 7%

    • Needham & Company lowers its Silicon Motion Technology (NASDAQ:SIMO) price target by $2 to $54 and maintains a Buy rating following the company lowering Q2 revenue estimates to below previous guidance and consensus.
    • The adjustment was due to the impact of NAND industry tightness impacting Silicon Motion’s SSD segment. 
    • Analyst Rajvindra Gill now forecasts SSD sales growth of 6% on the year, down from the previous estimate of 20%. 
    • Gill expects design wins to pick up business in the second half of the year, but visibility remains limited. 
    • Source: StreetInsider 
    • Silicon Motion shares are down 7.25%.         
    • Previously: Silicon Motion preliminary Q2 results below consensus; shares drop 8.6% premarket (July 7)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:32 PM
  • OCLR

    Analyst raises Oclaro price target, calls an M&A target; shares up over 4%

    • Stifel raises its Oclaro (NASDAQ:OCLR) price target by $2 to $12 and maintains a Buy rating.
    • Analyst Patrick Newton attributes the change to increased confidence in the sustainability of CFP2-ACO revenue, expectations for substantial QSFP28 sales growths, and a belief that the Chinese market is “de-risked” from analyst estimates.
    • Newton calls Oclaro “a logical M&A candidate.” 
    • Firm lists FY19 revenue and EPS guidance of $710M and $0.80, respectively. 
    • Source: StreetInsider. 
    • Oclaro shares are up 4.16%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 3:20 PM | 4 Comments

  • Technology - Top Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: DGLY +31%. COGT +13%. AAOI +11%. SCWX +7%. CSLT +8%.
    • Losers: RSYS -16%. DMRC -16%. MSDI -13%. ABIL -10%. SIMO -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM
  • VLO

    Bloomberg: U.S. unlikely to sanction Venezuelan crude

    • The Trump administration is unlikely to ban imports of Venezuelan crude oil even as it considers sanctions on the country’s energy sector, Bloomberg reports.
    • The cautious stance comes as refiners lobby in D.C. against the move, which would choke off supplies to U.S. refineries reliant on Venezuelan crude, including those owned by Valero Energy (VLO +2.6%), Phillips 66 (PSX +1%) and Chevron (CVX -0.6%).
    • The largest trade group for U.S. refiners say sanctions limiting U.S. imports of Venezuelan crude especially would hurt Gulf coast and east coast refineries that have optimized to utilize sour crudes produced in Venezuela.
    • Venezuela was the second largest supplier of crude oil in 2016 to the Gulf Coast, with 701K bbl/day, and all U.S. refineries imported 24.4M barrels of crude from the country in April.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 15 Comments
  • HP

    "Prolonged stagnation" for oil prices prompts three Wells Fargo downgrades

    • Oilfield services stocks Helmerich & Payne (HP -1.3%), Nabors Industries (NBR -5.1%) and Oil States (OIS -1.1%) are downgraded at Wells Fargo, which believes rising U.S. production raises the odds of a “prolonged stagnation” in oil prices that will hurt energy firms’ spending outlooks over the next few years.
    • Wells lowers its outlook for international spending and margins and forecasts a growing disparity in the U.S. between rig count and stage count beginning in H217.
    • In addition to downgrading HP to Underperform from Market Perform with a $45 price target, cut from $62.50, and NBR and OIS to Market Perform from Outperform, the firm says it is shifting more North American-leveraged small- and mid-caps up its oilfield services rankings, such as RPC Corp. (RES -2.2%), U.S. Silica (SLCA -9.5%) and Select Energy Services (WTTR -1.8%).
     
     
     
     
    | 2:37 PM | 15 Comments
  • ETH

    Cautious Dougherty note out on Ethan Allen

    • Ethan Allen (NYSE:ETH) is sharply lower after Dougherty exudes caution in a new note to clients ahead of the retailer's Q2 report.
    • The firm points to soft traffic trends and a disappointing level of consumer interest in the Disney Collection despite higher TV advertising.
    • Source: Bloomberg
    • Shares of Ethan Allen are down 3.72% and slipped below $30 for the first time in two weeks.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:28 PM

  • Energy/Materials - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: ZN +41%. TGB +7%. CIE +6%.
    • Losers: FMSA -15%. SND -14%. HCLP -10%. SLCA -9%. PES -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM | 2 Comments

  • Rebounding tech leads markets higher

    • The threat of hawkish central banks amid fancy valuations has been spooking markets just a bit of late, particularly tech. A strong jobs report this morning would seemingly reinforce that view, but an afternoon rally is underway.
    • It's being led by the Nasdaq's 1.35% gain, reversing and more its big drop from yesterday, and bringing the index back to about unchanged on the week.
    • The S&P 500 is up 0.65%, and the DJIA up 0.45%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:53 PM
  • TAHO

    Tahoe Resources -39% in two days after Escobal mining license suspended

    • Tahoe Resources (TAHO -7.5%) extends its two-day decline to all-time lows after Guatemala’s Supreme Court issued a provisional decision to temporarily revoke the license for its flagship Escobal mine in Guatemala in response to a lawsuit against the country’s mining ministry.
    • At least six sell-side firms have since weighed in with downgrades and reduced financial estimates, including RBC Capital, BMO Capital, TD Securities, Credit Suisse, Raymond James and Macquarie.
    • In cutting shares to Sector Perform from Outperform. RBC says it assumes Escobal operations will resume within three months but expects the various related legal and regulatory processes could remain an overhang during the next 12-18 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:49 PM | 24 Comments
  • RMBS

    Rambus reportedly mulling a sale; shares up 13% and halted

    • Rambus (NASDAQ:RMBS) has spiked more than 13% on a Bloomberg report that the company has hired an adviser to explore a sale. Shares are currently on volatility halt.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:31 PM | 7 Comments

  • Silver tumbles to more than a one-year low

    • Currently down 3.4% to $15.44 per ounce, silver is at its weakest since the spring of 2016.
    • The metal last night suffered something like a flash crash, tumbling a full 11% to $14.34 in a matter of minutes on what may have been computer-generated trading. It quickly recovered most of that loss, but started sliding again following the jobs beat at 8:30 ET.
    • SLV -3.4%
    • ETFs: SLV, AGQ, PSLV, USLV, SIVR, ZSL, SLVO, DSLV, DBS, USV, SHNY, DULL
     
     
     
     
    | 1:28 PM | 127 Comments

  • Financials - Top Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: MLP +6%. LGIH +5%.
    • Losers: PN -12%. LOAN -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:03 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: ZN +39%. DGLY +28%. AVEO +13%. TXMD +12%. MOSY +11%. RADA +10%. INSG +10%. SPKE +10%. ARNA +10%. DSPG +8%.
    • Losers: CERC -35%. CHKE -35%. OTCPK:IMUC -28%. APHB -21%. KTOV -20%. RSYS -18%. OCUL -16%. DCIX -15%. DMRC -14%. PN -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:41 PM | 4 Comments
  • DTEGY

    Deutsche Telekom reviewing Europe media strategy amid change

    • Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY -0.2%) is pursuing a realignment of its media strategy in the face of a rapidly changing industry that is forcing new convergences between telecom firms, media companies and advertisers.
    • The company's "Project Tetris" is a comprehensive review of its approach that might end up in dividing its European media operation into six different groups with agency duties divided to align with those, The Wall Street Journal reports.
    • Taking part in the review: Omnicom (OMC -0.1%), WPP (WPPGY -1.8%) and Publicis Groupe (PUBGY -3.5%).
    • A company document that WSJ saw points to the need to draw consumers whose attention is moving quickly toward mobile devices and who are using ad blockers in increasing numbers. It says traditional TV (about a third of its media spend) will decline "slightly" while print, out-of-home and radio (about another third) will drop "sharply."
    • DT spends hundreds of millions of dollars in regional media.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:16 PM
  • X

    EU says "ready to react" if U.S. imposes punitive steel tariffs

    • Steel names (SLX -1.4%) are broadly lower following headlines suggesting that the European Union may retaliate against the U.S. if steel tariffs are put into effect.
    • "Should the U.S. introduce tariffs on European steel imports, Europe is ready to react immediately and adequately," European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said today at the G20 summit in Hamburg.
    • X -4.6%, NUE -1.8%, AKS -4.6%, STLD -2.7%, SCHN -3.8%, MT -1%, CLF -1.8%, RS -1.6%, WOR -0.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:02 PM | 60 Comments

  • Consumer - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: SORL +6%.
    • Losers: WPRT -7%. OSK -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM | 1 Comment
  • ABS

    Albertson's said to be mystery WFM bidder

    • Albertson's (NYSE:ABS) is the company that offered to buy Whole Foods Market (WFM +0.3%) for $35 to $40 per share, according to Reuters.
    • If the sourced report is accurate, it's a miss for Cerberus Capital, which owns grocery store chains Albertson's and Safeway.
    • Today's development on "Company X" in the Amazon-Whole Foods bidding process has sent shares of Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM +3.8%) and Natural Grocers by Vitamin Cottage (NGVC +2.1%) higher.
    • Previously: Amazon outbid 'Party X' for Whole Foods (July 7)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:43 AM | 19 Comments
  • LGIH

    LGI Homes +5.6%; leads homebuilders higher after record Q2

    • The company last night announced record June home closings of 623 vs. 355 a year ago. For all Q2, closings of 1,511 were also a record, and up from 1,128 a year earlier.
    • For H1, closings of 2,272 homes were up 15.2% Y/Y.
    • LGIH +5.6%
    • Peers: D.R. Horton (DHI +3.4%), Toll Brothers (TOL +3.1%), KB Home (KBH +2%), PulteGroup (PHM +2.1%), Lennar (LEN +2.8%), Hovnanian (HOV +2.9%), NVR (NVR +2.2%)
    • ETFs: ITB +2.1%, XHB +1.4%
     
     
     
     
    | 11:40 AM | 1 Comment
  • CLF

    Cliffs Natural started as a Buy at Jefferies on U.S. steel market strength

    • Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF -1.6%) is initiated with a Buy rating and a $9 price target at Jefferies, which calls CLF an "under-recognized beneficiary of U.S. steel market strength."
    • CLF's focus on premium pellets is "a defensive positive" as ongoing supply growth weighs on seaborne iron ore, Jefferies says, and "current iron ore strength is a reminder Chinese steel restructuring could continue to support iron ore prices in months ahead."
    • The firm adds that pending trade protections may help ensure both higher ASPs and demand for CLF's high grade pellets into 2018.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:34 AM | 49 Comments
  • RSYS

    Analyst lowers RadiSys price target after preliminary Q2 results

    • Needham & Company lowers the price target for RadiSys (NASDAQ:RSYS) to $4.50 from $5 but maintains a Buy rating.
    • The price target shift follows RadiSys’ preliminary Q2 results, which lowered revenue estimates from the previous guidance. 
    • RadiSys shares are down 16.66% to $3.   
    • Previously: Radisys lowers Q2 revenue estimate below consensus (July 6)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:21 AM | 2 Comments
  • SNBR

    Mattress stocks tilt lower again after Wedbush warns

    • Wedbush Securities warns on a sluggish end to the quarter in the mattress sector, citing additional risk for Select Comfort (SCSS -4.2%) in particular. Yesterday, KeyBanc pointed to delivery delay times for Select Comfort based on its channel checks.
    • Tempur Sealy (NYSE:TPX) is down 1% on the day to extend on yesterday's decline.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:07 AM
  • XOM

    Oil prices plunge 3% as signs of oversupplied market persist

    • The S&P 500 energy index sinks to its lowest level since April 2016, with U.S. crude oil now -2.9% to $44.20/bbl following EIA data that showed continued strength in U.S. oil production in the final week of June just as OPEC exports hit a 2017 high, casting doubt over efforts by producers to curb oversupply.
    • "Following a sharp rally which was mostly driven by short-covering, the failure of Brent to break back above $50 earlier in the week has once again given sellers appetite for sending it lower," says Ole Hansen, head of commodity strategy at Saxo Bank.
    • XOM -0.1%, CVX -0.7%, RDS.A -0.9%, BP -0.6%, COP -1.5%, OXY -1.3%, APC -1.4%, DVN -3.2%, CLR -3.9%, SWN -3.3%, WPX -3.9%, NFX -1.8%, HES -3.3%, NBR -6.1%, QEP -6.2%, WLL -6.7%, ECA -3.3%, EOG -1.5%, WFT -4.7%, HAL -1.6%, SLB -0.7%.
    • ETFs: USO, XLE, OIL, UWT, UCO, VDE, DWT, ERX, XOP, SCO, OIH, BNO, GASL, FCG, DBO, ERY, DIG, DTO, BGR, XES, USL, FENY, DUG, IYE, GUSH, IEO, DRIP, FIF, DNO, IEZ, GASX, PXE, NDP, OLO, PXI, RYE, SZO, PXJ, PSCE, FXN, OLEM, CRAK, DDG, NANR, OILK, WTIU, SOP, UOP, OILX, WTID, USOI
     
     
     
     
    | 11:07 AM | 197 Comments

  • Healthcare - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 11:00 am

    • Gainers: MEIP +12%. AVEO +11%. TYHT +8%. ARNA +8%. TXMD +8%.
    • Losers: CERC -34%. OTCPK:IMUC -24%. KTOV -20%. APHB -14%. OCUL -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:01 AM | 6 Comments
  • HAIN

    Food sector on watch after Campbell Soup goes shopping

    • Dealreporter thinks that recent activity in the food sector could spark interest in Hain Celestial (HAIN +2.2%).
    • Campbell Soup acquired Pacific Foods at 3.2X trailing one-year revenue and Lactalis picked up Stonyfield for 2.4X 2016 sales, according to Bloomberg.
    • Gainers in the food sector today on the same sort of M&A speculation include Amplify Snack Brands (BETR +4.4%), Central Garden & Pet (CENT +3.4%), Freshpet (FRPT +1.6%) and Amira Nature Foods (ANFI +0.7%).
    • Previously: Campbell Soup acquires Pacific Foods (July 6)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:52 AM | 4 Comments

  • Priced in? Financials slip after jobs beat

    • The XLF is higher by 9%, and KRE and KBE each by more than 6% since June 1, suggesting the good news on the economy and interest rates embedded in this morning's strong jobs report has been priced into the financials.
    • The sector is thus taking a breather this morning, with the XLF flat, and KRE and KBE each down 0.45% vs. the S&P 500's 0.35% advance.
    • Also taking a breather from its fast rise is the yield on the 10-year Treasury. It's up just one basis point to 2.38%. One month ago, it stood at about 2.12%.
    • ETFs: XLF, FAS, FAZ, KRE, VFH, UYG, KBE, IYF, FNCL, BTO, IAT, IYG, KBWB, QABA, FXO, SEF, KBWR, RYF, FINU, XLFS, DPST, KRU, FINZ, RWW, WDRW, KRS, FAZZ, JHMF, FTXO, FNCF
     
     
     
     
    | 10:47 AM | 3 Comments

  • Natural gas inventory builds slightly more than expected

    • EIA Natural Gas Inventory: +72 Bcf vs. +64 Bcf consensus, +46 Bcf last week.
    • Futures +1.21% to $2.923.
    • ETFs: UNG, DGAZ, UGAZ, BOIL, GAZ, KOLD, UNL,DCNG.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:30 AM | 28 Comments
  • ZN

    Zion Oil spikes after drilling operations update, end to unit program

    • Zion Oil & Gas (ZN +17.7%) surges higher to cap a near doubling over the past five trading sessions.
    • Yesterday, ZN said it would not extend its current $250 unit program under its dividend reinvestment and common stock purchase plan beyond July 12.
    • ZN also said it was continuing active drilling operations at its Megiddo-Jezreel well in Israel, reaching a depth of ~3,280 ft. toward a proposed total depth of up to 15K ft.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:21 AM | 3 Comments
  • MSI

    Motorola Solutions wins $461.3M Army radio contract

    • Motorola Solutions (MSI +1.7%) has nailed down a $461.25M contract with the Army on mobile radios.
    • It's a firm-fixed-price deal in which the company will support the capability to upgrade and modernize land mobile radio system infrastructure and update technology to the latest systems.
    • Work will take place at locations to be determined and completed by July 6, 2022.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:16 AM | 1 Comment
  • FTR

    Frontier Communications -4.6% as it preps reverse split

    • Frontier Communications (NYSE:FTR) is 4.6% lower after news that it will implement its 1-for-15 reverse stock split over the weekend.
    • The move's effective with the start of trading Monday. Shares will still trade on Nasdaq under FTR but with a new CUSIP.
    • The stock's down to $1.05 after hanging around the $2 mark as recently as April. Shares are down 68.5% YTD and are down 78.3% over the past 12 months (it was at $5.20 last July 29).
     
     
     
     
    | 9:43 AM | 46 Comments
  • LBCC

    Long Island Iced Tea announces share offering

    • Long Island Iced Tea (LTEA) announced the signing of subscription agreements for a public offering of 448,160 shares at an offering price of $5.00 per share.
    • The offering is expected to close on July 12.
    • Source: Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 9:43 AM
  • GSAT

    Globalstar -3.4% as filing details lending changes

    • Globalstar (NYSEMKT:GSAT) is 3.4% lower after filing a new 8-K that sets up new agreements between the company and bankers.
    • Globalstar entered into a deal with Thermo Funding Company that includes deferring some financial covenants, extending the time for Equity Cure Contributions and eliminating a requirement for Globalstar to redeem its 8% notes, among others.
    • The two also entered a deal where Thermo Funding II bought 17.84M shares of voting common stock for $1.85/share, a 10% discount to the company's June 29 close. Shares are down to $2.01 in the opening minute this morning.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:33 AM | 20 Comments

  • Premarket Losers as of 9:05 am

    • CERC -26%.
    • MSDI -12%.
    • AIRI -10% on announcing pricing of its common stock.
    • APHB -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:13 AM

  • Premarket Gainers as of 9:05 am

    • DGLY +54% on patent victory over Axon.
    • GLBS +26% on Q1 results.
    • AFSI +10% on reinsurance deal.
    • AVEO +9%.
    • VSTM +7% ahead of trial.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:12 AM | 1 Comment
  • CHKE

    Cherokee plunges after surprise FQ1 loss

    • Shares of Cherokee (NASDAQ:CHKE) are down 24% in premarket trading after the company posted a FQ1 loss instead of the profitable quarter anticipated by analysts. Royalty revenue plunged during the quarter as a shift to wholesales licenses was executed.
    • The company is looking for a bounce back in the second half.
    • "The theme of domestic expansion continues with our Tony Hawk brand where, in partnership with our new U.S. wholesale licensees, we have secured orders for an expanded distribution of Hawk products starting this July," notes Cherokee's CEO.
    • Investors have their eyes on Cherokee's lack of compliance with the terms of a credit facility with Cerberus. Cherokee says it's negotiating with Cerberus.
    • Previously: Cherokee misses by $0.20, beats on revenue (July 6)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:09 AM | 8 Comments

  • More gains for loonie after strong Canada jobs print

    • Canada added 45.3K jobs in June, far exceeding expectations for just 10K. The unemployment rate ticked down to 6.5% vs. 6.6% expected.
    • Economy bears will point out that most of the new jobs were part-time.
    • Nevertheless, the report is sure to fuel those who believe the Bank of Canada will hike rates next week.
    • The loonie (NYSEARCA:FXC) is up 0.6% vs. the greenback at a nearly one-year high of $0.7753.
    • ETFs: EWC, CNDA, EWCS, QCAN, FCAN, HEWC
     
     
     
     
    | 9:06 AM
  • ARNA

    Analyst upgrades Arena ahead of Phase 2 readouts; shares up 4.8% premarket

    • JMP upgrades Arena Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ARNA) from Market Perform to Outperform and initiates a $27 price target.
    • Analyst Jason Butler upgraded Arena ahead of the Phase 2 data results expected later this year for Ralinepag for pulmonary arterial hypertension (readout in July) and etrasimod for ulcerative colitis (readout by year’s end). 
    • Butler finds that Arena’s current valuation misses the potential for clinical and commercial successes particularly with “blockbuster asset” etrasimod. 
    • Analyst standings on Arena: 3 Buys and 4 Holds. 
    • Average price target: $34. 
    • Source: Bloomberg 
    • Arena shares are up 4.84% premarket.         
     
     
     
     
    | 9:00 AM | 10 Comments
  • AFSI

    AmTrust up almost 10% after reinsurance deal as sell-side applauds

    • KBW's Meyer Shields is a fan, saying the deal cuts the risk of further adverse loss reserve development, and does so at a reasonable price. He lifts his 2017 and 2018 EPS estimates by a nickel to $1.70 and $2.10, respectively. He boosts 2019 by $0.15 to $2.25.
    • A bull on the stock, FBR's Randy Binner nevertheless cuts his 2017 and 2018 estimates thanks to now lower net investment income. Should shares sell off, buy the dip, he says.
    • JMP's Matthew Carletti reinstates coverage with a Market Outperform rating and $18 price target. He likes the lower likelihood of reserve charges hurting results, but says improved disclosure and remediation of material weaknesses are needed for the stock to achieve a market multiple.
    • Source: Lily Katz at Bloomberg
    • AFSI +9.35% to $14.76
    • Previously: AmTrust enters reinsurance deal with Premia; to take $61M charge (July 6)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:58 AM | 1 Comment
  • SIMO

    Silicon Motion preliminary Q2 results below consensus; shares drop 8.6% premarket

    • Silicon Motion (NASDAQ:SIMO) announces preliminary Q2 results with revenue expected slightly below guidance of $134M to $140M. Consensus estimates put revenue at $136.32.
    • Gross margin expected at low end of guidance between 48.5% and 50.5%.
    • Silicon Motion shares are down 8.6% premarket.   
     
     
     
     
    | 8:51 AM | 7 Comments
  • NADL

    North Atlantic Drilling wins another delay on rig delivery

    • North Atlantic Drilling (NYSE:NADL) +9.4% premarket on news it has extended the delivery deferral period for the West Rigel semi-submersible drilling rig from Jurong Shipyard by six months to next January, which will allow the companies to continue to explore commercial opportunities for the unit.
    • The extension is the latest delivery delay for the rig, which originally was scheduled for delivery in Q1 2015.
    • If no employment is secured for unit and no alternative transaction is completed, NADL and Jurong would form a joint asset holding company to be owned 23% by NADL and 77% by Jurong.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:47 AM

  • Yields back on the rise after jobs beat

    • Alongside the 222K job gain in June, May's 138K print was revised up to 152K, and April's 174K up to 207K.
    • The unemployment rate did tick up to 4.4%, but this came alongside an increase in the labor force participation rate to 62.8% from 62.7%.
    • The average workweek rose by 0.1 hour to 34.5 hours. Average hourly earnings rose by $0.04 to $26.25 - they're up 2.5% Y/Y.
    • The 10-year Treasury yield is up 2.3 basis points to 2.39%. TLT -0.55%, TBT +1.1%
    • The strong report isn't yet helping the dollar (UUP, UDN). It was higher earlier in the session, but has returned to flat.
    • Gold (NYSEARCA:GLD) remains marginally lower on the session.
    • Stock index futures (SPY, QQQ, DIA) remain modestly in the green.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:45 AM | 18 Comments
  • CABGY

    Barclays warns on Carlsberg keeping up with peers

    • Barclays warns that Carlsberg's (OTCPK:CABGY) natural beer volume growth rate of 0.6% per year is less than half the expected pace of Anheuser-Bsuch InBev or Heineken.
    • Carlsberg is seen facing challenges with a new trade channel in Russia and F/X headwinds in key markets.
    • Barclays lowers its rating on Carlsberg to Underweight from Equal-weight.
    • Source: Bloomberg
    • Shares of Carlsberg are down 1.5% in Copenhagen trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:30 AM
